Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Kevin Moeller of the Department of Chemistry at Washington University in St. Louis will explore the chemistry of highly reactive radical cation intermediates and the molecular transformations that they trigger. The radical cation intermediates are generated electrochemically, a versatile technique that allows for structure-reactivity studies to be conducted on the radical cations. These studies serve to increase our mechanistic insight into the factors that control radical cation initiated reactions, and in so doing open up the opportunity to discover new synthetic methods for the construction of complex organic molecules.

Since the electrochemical methods being developed can be conducted with the use of sunlight as the source of electricity, the chemistry holds great potential as a sustainable method. For example, chemical oxidation reactions utilize stoichiometric amounts of a chemical oxidant and in so doing require the formation of a stoichiometric reduction product as waste. In contrast, electrochemical oxidation reactions do not employ a chemical oxidant. Instead, the oxidation occurs by the loss of an electron to an anode surface. The required reduction reaction is channeled toward the formation of hydrogen gas at the cathode. Hence, a solar-driven electrochemical oxidation consumes only sunlight and generates hydrogen as the only byproduct. The proposed research will seek to expand this approach as a general synthetic method. Finally, this project will provide an excellent training environment for students, from pre-undergraduate to graduate, including those from historically underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: From pharmaceuticals, herbicides, pesticides, dyes and food preservatives to materials found in cell phones, tires, and plastics chemical compounds frequently define our modern lives and the quality of those lives. For this reason, the chemical industry remains one of the largest, most profitable industries in our nation.   

Yet while this industry continues to thrive, it is also faced with many challenges. Often, building the molecules and materials needed by society is not a clean process. The chemical reactions utilized produce waste products that can have a strong negative impact on the environment. For this reason, we need to improve the long-term sustainability of the chemical tools we employ. In this effort, oxidation and reduction reactions are key players. The reactions are essential in that they adjust the number of electrons surrounding a molecule that govern the molecule’s reactivity and behavior. However, the reactions are often defined as much by the waste products they produce as they are the synthetic transformations they accomplish. Every oxidation must generate at least one equivalent of a reduction waste product and every reduction must generate at least one equivalent of an oxidation product. Fortunately, there are solutions to these problems. For example, electrochemical oxidation reactions avoid the use of chemical reagents by employing electricity to effect the transformations.  The reactions can be conducted using sustainable sources of electricity and channel the required reduction reaction to the formation of benign hydrogen gas.

For this reason, our NSF funded project has been looking at electrochemical oxidative coupling reactions that serve to define and illustrate the types of processes that can be accomplished directly at an electrode surface. The reactions have illustrated how oxidation reactions can be used to trigger new transformations by reversing the normal polarity of functional groups, have furthered our understanding of the highly reactive intermediates that define the outcome of the transformations, have provided the insight necessary to better design and utilize electrochemical reactions, and have demonstrated that synthetically useful reactions can be accomplished using sunlight as the only energy source. More recent reactions have shown that the benign hydrogen gas byproduct does not have to be thrown out, but instead can be siphoned off for use as a reagent in other reactions. This improves the sustainability of not only the single oxidation reaction, but also a second reaction by eliminating any need to package and transport hydrogen gas.

The net result of the chemistry studied has been to define a new class of synthetically useful reactions while defining for the larger community how to think about both electrochemical and electron-transfer processes in general. We have found that most chemists already have the knowledge and skills they need to design and implement electrochemical reactions. The key is understanding the “language” of electrochemistry and how it relates to issues they already have experience dealing with.

 

Broader Impact: The broader impact of the work conducted has been both scientific and educational. On the scientific front, the work is making electrochemistry more accessible to the larger chemistry community. For all of its advantages, electrochemical reactions are vastly underutilized by the synthetic community. This lack of utility often stems from the community’s lack of understanding of the reactions, both in terms of how to effect the transformations and in terms of what they can accomplish. In this light, the work being conducted is not only defining what can be accomplished with an electrochemical reaction, but also defining for the larger community how to think about electrochemical processes. Of course, this knowledge is only useful if we teach it to others. For that reason, we engage in a multi-prong education effort that includes giving seminars at both academic and industrial institutions, hosting visiting scientists in our labs so that they can learn electrochemical techniques, answering questions on the phone and in person about electrochemical methods and how to run specific reactions of interest, and developing lab experiments that can be taught to younger students so that they have a familiarity with electrochemistry. The goal is to teach chemists how to run and develop their own electrochemical methods. 

In addition to these efforts, we have been engaging younger children in hands-on experiments focused on nurturing in them a fascination with all aspects of science. Much of this effort has focused on developing curriculum for students who obtain their science education in non-traditional environments like home-school programs run by zoos. The lessons focus on chemical concepts ranging from polymers to electron-transfer, sunlight, and energy, to DNA and how it codes for diversity.  


Last Modified: 10/22/2016
Modified by: William E Buhro

Image
  • Electrochemical reactions are used to generate reactive intermediates and new chemistry. A photovoltaic can be used to drive the reactions using sunlight as the only energy source.

    Public Domain
